{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3523417,"name":"G3 6740","username":"G3_6740","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/3d9bf3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-11T15:35:31.331Z","cooked":"

hello, we’ve been trying to set up some LEds on our robot but when we fired up the code only one LED lit up, not the first or last LED but one in the middle of the strip. we checked and all the other LEDs are getting power, the LED length is properly defined in the code and the the port is correctly defined.

thank you G3

For us to be able to help, we’ll need some more information.

  • How are you controlling your LEDs? Using the AddressableLED support on the Rio, or are you using 3rd-party hardware such as a Blinkin or CANdle?
  • If using AddressableLED, how is your LED strip powered?
  • Is the strip standard WS2812B LEDs, or something else?
  • Please provide a link to your code.

Not specific to the issue you described, but you have the LED color set to blue on every periodic loop, which will override the other commands and such that tell it to do different colors.

I think it’s not advised to power addressable LEDs off the RoboRio PWM rail. I’m not particularly experienced with circuits or LEDs, but I’ve heard before that the PWM rail might not supply enough current, and that its 6V output is technically too much for a 5V WS2812B LED strip.

My team last year powered our LEDs with a 5V voltage regulator on a circuit off a Mini Power Module, and just wired signal to a pin on the Rio; this worked really well for us. One thing would be to make sure the regulator supplies enough current for the number of LEDs it’s powering, but IIRC we cut it close with 102 LEDs on a 3A supply and didn’t run into any issues.

I think another alternative for powering LEDs is the Rev Blinkin, although I’ve never used one on a robot so I don’t have much to say about it.
